title: What are the best online philosophy communities? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are a number of forums that tend to be attended to by philosophers, the most prevalent of which is Philosophy Forums (which is just as active today as when I found it in high school some seven years ago). Forums are great as online communities as you can engage in debate somewhat more easily than Quora allows. Forums tend to have fewer laymen and support somewhat more rigor than other social platforms. Next to Philosophy Forums would have to be Twitter. While 140 characters seems rather tight, there is considerable discourse online (often extended by blog post exchanges). And, despite the tight discourse (as philosophical as it may be), there is also a great number of philosophers on Twitter, a great portion of whom are academics and students of philosophy. One person in particular, Rani Lill Anjum maintains lists of  Philosophers on Twitter, which count more than 1,300 as of this answer. It is an amazing way to network, and my studies (let alone my general philosophical disposition) have benefited greatly from the vast and accessible network of philosophers on Twitter. Beyond these two larger communities, there are less 'maintained' communities such as those on Reddit, and those here on Quora, and your own personal communities (friends and groups on Facebook!). Academia.edu could also be a great resource (though I admittedly only currently use it to stalk pre-publication papers and thesis work). And, of course, the best communities are those offline, where you can meet up and stroke beards in person, be it through faculty and academia, journal clubs, across the cafe tables, or under a tree.

There are many places, and foremost may very well be http://Quora.com A search on the Internet using terms like; “discussion forums” + “philosophy” can show many. Otherwise, you can research “Argumentation Theory” and “Pragma Dialectics” or “The Ten Rules” Study the Ten Rules of Pragma Dialectics (Rules for dialogue) #1 The Freedom Rule #2 The Burden of Proof Rule #3 The Stand Point Rule #4 The Relevance Rule #5 The Unexpressed Premise Rule #6 The Starting Point Rule #7 The Argumentative Scheme Rule #8 The Validity Rule #9 The Closure Rule #10 The Usage Rule The one subject which permeates all of philosophy is The Mind/Body Problem (often referred to as the MBP) The ancient people had a saying; “All roads lead to Rome”. In a similar way, all discussions in philosophy lead to the MBP. Be prepared for that if you will.
